attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    A physical stock count was carried out on June 28th 2025. The purpose of this exercise was to verify the accuracy of the inventory balances in the SAP system and to assess the effectiveness of internal controls related to inventory management and recording at the branch.
•    A few discrepancies in the inventory records were observed as illustrated below:
a)    Bread stock showed a total surplus of 11 loaves,
b)    Polybags had a shortage of 71 pieces,
c)    Other stock items had minimal or nil variation as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch manager should implement stricter controls around yield recording, especially for bread production, to prevent over- or under-reporting of bread as this also will reduce instances of weight issues.
•    Branch management to establish routine follow-ups on damaged items such as polybags ensuring records are maintained
attributes.effect:
•    The discrepancies identified during the physical stock count indicate potential weaknesses in inventory recording and control processes at the branch. Specifically: 
a)    The surplus in bread stock may point to inaccurate yield recording or stock mismanagement, leading to overstatement of inventory.
b)    The shortage in polybags suggests possible loss, damage, or recording errors, which could result in understated inventory or unnoticed shrinkage
c)    The recurring nature of variances, as seen in the prior audit report, suggests that the internal control issues have not been fully addressed

value:
•    We will follow up on polybag damages to make sure they are recorded accurately. We will also focus on tracking damages and packed bread for each shift.
•    The issue might of excess bread stock can be caused by incorrect yield recording. We will check on this to ensure it is recorded correctly.

•    In the prior audit report dated 15th  May 2025 stock take reveled the following:
a)    Polybags -74 Pieces.
b)    Bread stock had a negative variance of 8.5 Loaves.
c)    All other materials had negligible variations.
d)    Crates had a nil variance.
A physical stock count was done on 28th June 2025 to verify inventory records in SAP and assess internal control over stock management.
Bread had a surplus (11 loaves), and polybags had a shortage (71 pieces). The inconsistencies suggest gaps in yield recording and control over damaged materials.
To confirm the accuracy of recorded stock balances and identify any discrepancies.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit of the mixing chart and mixing chart summary was conducted over a 31-day period (30th May to 29th June 2025) to evaluate production efficiency, resource utilization (specifically Utto consumption) and compliance with the Bill of Materials (BOM) and quality standards. 
•    The analysis revealed the following:
a)    Utto consumption stood at 100%.
b)    The average yield was 191.00 loaves per bag.
c)    Average production was 35.03 bags per day, this represents 77.85% of the set target of 45 bags.
d)    There were 793 remixes for the period audited.
•    Below is a summary of the audit finding:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management for the remaining days should review shift scheduling and production plans to optimize output, considering market demands
attributes.effect:
•    The production lack of target attainment indicate underperformance in meeting production goals. This shortfall could impact sales fulfillment and overall profitability.
•    Compared to the prior audit, production and remix figures show a trend that requires ongoing attention to improve operational efficiency and resource utilization.

value:
•    Occasionally, we adjusted shift production (Shifts Cut) based on sales demand and transfers because we have only one vehicle available.
•    At Remixes, frequent oven breakdowns caused production to be halted for much of the day. Although operations are now stable, delays in repairs were mainly due to spare parts availability issues.

•    In the Prior Audit, audit findings were as follows: 
a)    Average production was 38.76 bags equivalent to 86.13% of the set target of 45 bags.
b)    Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
c)    The average yield was 190.99 loaves per bag.
d)    There were 585 cases of remixes for the period.
A review of daily mixing chart summaries was carried out for the period under audit.
Average production (35.03 bags/day) was below the target of 45 bags/day (77.85% attainment), with 793 remixes recorded. Frequent oven breakdowns and shift cuts contributed to the underperformance.
Operations/Production Department
To assess production performance against targets, remix occurrences, and resource usage (Utto consumption).

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was carried out to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded cash balance in the cash flow records. This was also intended to assess the effectiveness of cash handling and management controls.
•    It was noted detailed below.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management is recommended to perform a thorough cash verification and reconciliation routinely and before the branch transfer or closure to ensure all cash balances are accurate and accounted for.
attributes.effect:
•    The cash variance of Kshs. 170 indicates a minor discrepancy in cash handling, which, if left unaddressed, could lead to financial misstatements or loss of funds.
•    Previous audit findings of variance suggest a recurring challenge in cash management that needs resolution before closure or transfer to ensure a clean audit trail.

value:
•    We advised the cashier to keep some loose change on hand to make giving change easier.
•    Cashier remark:  The issue occurred because the change balance had not yet been returned at the time of the audit.

•    In prior audit,  A Variance of Kshs. +83 was noted and a pending IOU of cash Kshs. 10,200 that was paid to the county council for penalty for Parking KCC 337Z, that was passed 3-day clearance policy
A cash spot check was conducted to reconcile physical cash with book balances.
A minor variance of KSh 170 was found. Though small, such variances require attention, especially with previous recurring cash discrepancies.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate the accuracy of cash records and effectiveness of handling controls.

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check on the weights of packed bread scheduled for dispatch to the market was carried out on June 28th 2025, to assess compliance with KEBS standard weight requirements and the company standards.
•    The results showed mixed compliance across different bread varieties:
a)    The majority of the 400g bread samples (89%) met the standard weight, but a notable portion (9%) were underweight and 1% were overweight.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should continue rigorous weight monitoring to ensure all bread meets KEBS and company standards during the transition, even if production volumes are lower.
attributes.effect:
•    Regular distribution of underweight products can lead to customer complaints, loss of trust and damage to the brand’s image 
•    Overweight loaves may increase costs unnecessarily, which is critical when raw materials are being tightly controlled and ordered only as needed.
•    Failure to meet KEBS weight standards could lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and potential financial losses.

value: •    We shall maintain the trend to ensure majority of bread produced is of correct weight.

•    The previous audit report dated 15th  May 2025; Dough weight
a)    Avg. Overweight-26%
b)    Avg. Under Weight-68%
c)    Overall avg. Weight-469.55
•    Packed bread
a)    400 g of butter was 39% underweight
b)    And 400 g CTW was 29% underweight
A spot check on bread weights was done on 28th June to assess compliance with KEBS and internal standards.
89% of 400g bread samples met weight standards, with 9% underweight. The improvement is commendable, but ongoing monitoring is necessary.
Operations/Production Department
To verify whether bread being dispatched met regulatory and internal weight requirements.

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An in-depth analysis was conducted to assess the levels of bread damage arising from both production defects and market-related issues during the period from 30th May 2025 to 29th June 2025. The objective was to determine whether the branch was adhering to the established quality control standards.
•    We noted the following:
a)    Production-related damages accounted for 0.210% of the total production volume, which is slightly above the acceptable KPI limit of 0.20%. 
b)    Market-related damages stood at 0.48% of total sales, which is within the KPI limit of 0.50%.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

NB: The analysis is exclusive of 177oven damages
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management is encouraged to ensure staff follow proper procedures to reduce production damages, especially during this final phase when every loaf counts due to limited raw material supply.
attributes.effect:
Production damage: Although the deviation from the KPI is minor, it occurs during a period of controlled production with raw materials being supplied strictly on a per-request basis. This means that any avoidable damage results in a proportionally higher cost impact.
•    Market-level damages still represent lost sales and product wastage at a time when product availability must be tightly aligned with demand.

value:
•    The issue of production damages was caused by an oven breakdown, which affected the bread production. We will ensure that production does not exceed the set limits moving forward.
•    We will also emphasize proper packing and handling of bread to further minimize such occurrences.

•    In the prior audit dated 15th May 2025,
a)    Production damages were at 0.21% of total production which exceeded the set limit of 0.2% 
b)    Market damages stood at 0.41% of total sales, which was within the allowable limit of 0.5%
A damage analysis was performed to determine compliance with acceptable limits (0.20% for production, 0.50% for market).
Production damages (0.210%) slightly exceeded the target, while market damages (0.48%) remained within range. Oven issues contributed to production losses.
To assess bread damage levels and evaluate their impact on cost and quality.

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit verification was conducted to confirm that all bread damages reported as transferred to the Ingredients Department were either physically accounted for or accurately recorded in line with established procedures.
•    The audit revealed inconsistencies in record-keeping during the review period. On several occasions, the quantity of bread damages reported as transferred exceeded the actual physical damages observed at the branch. This recurring discrepancy suggests potential issues with documentation accuracy or unrecorded sources of damage not properly tracked in the system.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management is encouraged to conduct a full and final reconciliation of all bread damages and their corresponding transfers to the Ingredients Department before branch closure.
attributes.effect: •    The audit identified inconsistencies between the bread damages reported as transferred to the Ingredients Department and the actual physical balances. This raises concerns about the accuracy and reliability of damage records, especially during a critical phase of branch closure.

value: •    I will continue to follow up during the remaining period to ensure accurate recording and help minimize such issues.
•    In the previous audit report, it was observed that there was less damages balance sent to the Ingredients department to the tune of 5.65kgs attributed to moisture loss.
Reconciliation was done between recorded bread damages and actual transfers to the Ingredients Department.
A variance of 6.39kg was noted, pointing to inaccurate damage records or tracking errors.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure completeness and accuracy in documenting bread waste transferred for reuse.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was conducted to measure the efficiency of human resource utilization within the production department, focusing on whether staff were meeting the company’s target output of 5 bags per worker as outlined in the operational guidelines.
•    The analysis revealed that production efficiency was at 4.58 bags per production worker, which was slightly below  the standard rate of 5 bags as seen in the summary below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should avoid assigning production staff during shifts where no active production is scheduled. Only deploy labor based on clear, planned output to minimize idle labor costs.
attributes.effect:
•    The production efficiency falling short of the target indicates underutilization of manpower and this gap translates to additional labor costs.
•    As the branch approaches closure, inefficient resource allocation undermines cost control efforts during a period when production and staffing should be tightly aligned with actual demand and minimal waste.

value:
•    The shift cuts contributed to this issue, as there were instances where only one production staff member was assigned to complete pending work from a previous shift. 
•    However, on those specific shifts, no new production took place.
•    The previous audit report indicated a production efficiency of 4.79 bags per production worker.
Production labor output was analyzed to determine if staff met the target of 5 bags per worker.
Achieved output was 4.58 bags/worker, below the target. Underutilization of labor led to excess staffing costs of KSh 21,732.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate workforce productivity and cost efficiency.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency.
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was conducted to evaluate the efficiency of packers in the slicing section, aiming to determine if they met the company’s standard of 97 crates per packer.
•    The analysis covered the period from 30th  May 2025 to 29th June 2025 and revealed that the packing efficiency was slightly below the target, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Given the branch closure and controlled production, align packer staffing strictly with actual packing volumes to avoid excess labor costs.
attributes.effect:
•    Given that the branch is nearing closure and operating under controlled conditions, such inefficiencies can lead to unnecessary labor costs and resource wastage during a period when cost optimization is critical.
•    Continuing inefficiencies may affect the accuracy of final operational metrics.

value: •    During the period under review, we experienced a surge in orders which required additional manpower to support packing operations. The inefficiency was also partly due to issues with the slicer's new blade.
•    The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 93.70 crates per packer.
A review was done to assess the number of crates packed per worker versus the 97 crates target.
Packing efficiency was 96.10 crates/packer, slightly below target. One extra packer was hired, incurring a cost of KSh 912.
Operations/Production Department
To determine labor efficiency in the slicing and packing section.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was conducted on June 29th, 2025, at the Mini Shop to verify that all bread stock available for sale was properly recorded and that sales reported matched the payments collected through the designated Mpesa pay bill number. The Mini Shop follows a strict cashless policy.
•    The audit results are summarized below:
attributes.recommendation: Branch Management to maintain the existing controls
attributes.effect: •    The minimal variance (-0.2) between reported sales and Mpesa collections indicates strong control over sales recording and payment reconciliation.

value: •    Controls in place shall be maintained.
•    In the prior audit report,  It was noted that all sales were all accounted for
A spot check on 30th June reviewed sales vs. M-Pesa paybill records under the shop's cashless policy.
The negligible variance of KSh 0.20 indicates strong internal controls over sales recording.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm that sales were accurately recorded and payments received.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review was conducted on the branch of vehicles’ fuel consumption to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the month of May 2025 and for the period ended 29th June 2025

•    Motor vehicle consumption was well within the standards as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management to continue monitoring fuel issuance strictly based on actual kilometers traveled to prevent overconsumption or misuse during the remaining operational period.

value: •    We shall continue issuing fuel in regards to motor vehicle kms covered on a daily basis
•    During the previous audit  It was noted that fuel allocation was done as per the number of kilometers covered
Vehicle mileage and fuel usage were reviewed for the Mathare route.
Fuel use was within standard, showing a 5.14L saving—reflecting efficient vehicle management.
Transport/Fleet Department
To confirm that fuel issued matched distance covered and consumption standards.
